'''Bauhaus''' were an English [[rock music|rock]] band formed in [[Northampton]] in 1978. The group consisted of [[Peter Murphy (musician)|Peter Murphy]] (vocals), [[Daniel Ash]] (guitar), [[Kevin Haskins]] (drums), and [[David J]] (bass guitar). The band was originally '''Bauhaus 1919''' before they dropped the numerical portion within a year of formation. With their dark and gloomy sound and image, Bauhaus are generally considered the first [[gothic rock]] group.

Bauhaus first broke up in 1983. Peter Murphy began a solo career while the other members continued as [[Tones on Tail]] and, later, [[Love and Rockets (band)|Love and Rockets]]. Both enjoyed greater commercial success in the United States than Bauhaus had, but disappeared from the charts in their homeland. The band reunited for a 1998 tour and on a more permanent basis in 2005. The group announced plans to disband again following the release of their final album, ''[[Go Away White]]'', in 2008.

== History ==

Daniel Ash, his friend David J. Haskins, and Haskins' younger brother Kevin had played together in various bands since childhood. One of the longer-lived of these was a band called The Craze, which performed a few times around Northampton in 1978. However, The Craze still split up fairly quickly, and Ash once again tried to convince his old school friend Peter Murphy to join him, simply because Ash thought he had the right look for a band.&lt;ref&gt;Shirley, p. 18&lt;/ref&gt; Murphy, who was working in a printing factory, decided to give it a try, despite never having written any lyrics or music. During their first rehearsal, he co-wrote the song &quot;In the Flat Field&quot;.&lt;ref&gt;Thompson, p. 52&lt;/ref&gt;  Ash's old bandmate Kevin Haskins joined as the drummer. Ash made a point of not inviting David J, the driving force in their previous bands, because he wanted a band he could control.&lt;ref&gt;Shirley, p. 19&lt;/ref&gt; After only a few weeks though, Ash reconsidered and invited Haskins to replace original bassist Chris Barber. Haskins had already agreed to tour American airbases with another band, but decided that joining his friends' group was &quot;the right thing to do&quot;. With their line-up complete, the unnamed band played their first gig at the Cromwell pub in Wellingborough on New Year's Eve 1978.&lt;ref&gt;Shirley, p. 20&lt;/ref&gt;

The band chose the name Bauhaus 1919, a reference to the German [[Bauhaus]] art movement of the 1920s, because of its &quot;stylistic implications and associations&quot;, according to David J.&lt;ref&gt;Shirley, p. 21&lt;/ref&gt; The band also chose to use the same [[typeface]] used on the Bauhaus college building in [[Dessau]], [[Germany]]. Bauhaus associate Graham Bentley said that the group was unlike any Northampton band of the time, most of which played predominantly [[cover songs]].&lt;ref&gt;Shirley, p. 22&lt;/ref&gt; Bentley videotaped a performance by the group, which was sent to several record labels in the hope of obtaining a contract. This approach was hindered partly because many record companies at the time did not have home video equipment or Bentley had to provide it himself, so the group decided to record a demo.&lt;ref&gt;Shirley, pp.&amp;nbsp;23–24&lt;/ref&gt;

=== &quot;Bela Lugosi's Dead&quot; and 4AD ===
Together for only six weeks, Bauhaus entered the studio for the first time at Beck Studios in [[Wellingborough]] to record a demo.&lt;ref&gt;Shirley, pp.&amp;nbsp;25–26&lt;/ref&gt; The band recorded five songs; one of the tracks from the session, &quot;[[Bela Lugosi's Dead]]&quot;, running more than nine minutes, was released as the group's debut single in August 1979 on [[Small Wonder Records]] as Bauhaus (the 1919 abandoned).&lt;ref&gt;Shirley, pp.&amp;nbsp;28–29&lt;/ref&gt;&lt;ref&gt;Thompson, p. 59&lt;/ref&gt; The single received a positive review in ''Sounds'' and stayed on the British independent charts for two years. The song received crucial airplay on [[BBC Radio 1]] and DJ [[John Peel]]'s evening show, and Bauhaus was subsequently asked to record a session for Peel's show, which was broadcast on January 3, 1980.&lt;ref&gt;Shirley, p. 30&lt;/ref&gt;

The band released three more singles, &quot;[[Dark Entries]]&quot;, &quot;[[Terror Couple Kill Colonel]]&quot; and &quot;[[Telegram Sam]]&quot; — originally written by [[glam rock]] pioneers [[T. Rex (band)|T. Rex]] — before the debut of their first album ''[[In the Flat Field]]'' in 1980 on [[4AD]]. ''[[NME]]''  described it as &quot;Gothick-Romantick pseudo-decadence&quot;.&lt;ref&gt;{{Cite journal |last=Gill |first=Andy |title=Gothick as a brick [''In the Flat Field'' review] |journal=[[NME]] |pages=p32 |date=8 November 1980}}&lt;/ref&gt; Despite negative reviews, ''In the Flat Field'' topped the indie charts and made headway onto the British pop charts, peaking for one week at number 72.&lt;ref&gt;Shirley, p. 46&lt;/ref&gt;

=== Beggars Banquet and breakup ===

Bauhaus' growing success outstripped 4AD's resources, so the band moved to 4AD's parent label [[Beggars Banquet Records]].&lt;ref&gt;Shirley, p. 56&lt;/ref&gt; Bauhaus released &quot;[[Kick in the Eye]]&quot; as its debut release on the label. The single reached number 59 on the charts.&lt;ref&gt;Shirley, p. 57&lt;/ref&gt; the following single &quot;[[The Passion of Lovers]]&quot; peaked at number 56.&lt;ref&gt;Shirley, p. 60&lt;/ref&gt; Bauhaus released its second album, ''[[Mask (Bauhaus album)|Mask]]'', in October 1981. The band employed more keyboards and a variety of other instruments to add to the diversity of the record. In an unconventional move, the group shot a video for the album's title track as a promotional tool for the band as a whole and not any specific song from the record.&lt;ref&gt;Shirley, pp.&amp;nbsp;63–64&lt;/ref&gt;

Bauhaus followed with the single &quot;[[Spirit (Bauhaus song)|Spirit]]&quot;, produced by [[Hugh Jones (producer)|Hugh Jones]] and intended to break into the Top 30. However, &quot;Spirit&quot; only reached number 42. The band was displeased with the single and re-recorded it for their third album ''[[The Sky's Gone Out]]'', in 1982.&lt;ref&gt;Thompson, p. 115&lt;/ref&gt; In the same year Bauhaus scored their biggest hit with a cover of [[David Bowie]]'s &quot;[[Ziggy Stardust (song)|Ziggy Stardust]]&quot;, which was recorded during a BBC session. The song reached number 15 on the British charts and earned the band an appearance on the television show ''[[Top of the Pops]]''.&lt;ref&gt;Shirley, p. 78&lt;/ref&gt; Thanks to the success of the single, the album also became the band's biggest hit, peaking at number four.&lt;ref&gt;Shirley, p. 79&lt;/ref&gt; That same year Bauhaus made an appearance in the horror film ''[[The Hunger (1983 film)|The Hunger]]'', where they performed &quot;Bela Lugosi's Dead&quot; during the opening credits. The final cut of the scene focused on Murphy; this, coupled with the singer's modelling work in a popular ad campaign for [[Maxell]], caused resentment among the rest of the group.&lt;ref&gt;Shirley, pp.&amp;nbsp;91–93&lt;/ref&gt;

Prior to the recording of their fourth album ''[[Burning from the Inside]]'' (1983) Peter Murphy was stricken with pneumonia, which prevented him from contributing much to the album. Daniel Ash and David J took the reins and became the driving forces behind the record, and even did lead vocals on a few tracks.&lt;ref&gt;Shirley, pp.&amp;nbsp;96–97&lt;/ref&gt; The album's lead single, &quot;[[She's in Parties]]&quot;, reached number 26 on the charts and earned Bauhaus their third and final ''Top of the Pops'' appearance.&lt;ref&gt;Shirley, p. 99&lt;/ref&gt; Bauhaus then embarked on an international promotional tour for the album, with dates in Europe and the Far East.&lt;ref name=&quot;Thompson, p. 137&quot;&gt;Thompson, p. 137&lt;/ref&gt; David J recalled that the night before they were supposed to perform two shows at [[Hammersmith Palais]] in London the group decided to disband. The band played their farewell show on 5 July 1983 at the Hammersmith Palais; dedicated fans had been warned by the band's crew not to miss the show without telling them it was the last. After a long [[encore (concert)|encore]] consisting of some of their early songs, David J left the stage with the words &quot;rest in peace&quot;.&lt;ref name=&quot;Thompson, p. 137&quot;/&gt; ''Burning from the Inside'' was released a week later. The album received largely positive reviews and reached number 13 on the charts.&lt;ref&gt;Shirley, p. 100&lt;/ref&gt; Bauhaus released the single &quot;Sanity Assassin&quot; in limited quantities as a farewell gift for those who joined the group's fanclub.&lt;ref&gt;Shirley, p. 102&lt;/ref&gt;

=== Post-breakup ===

After Bauhaus disbanded, the members of the band did various solo work. Peter Murphy worked briefly with bassist [[Mick Karn]] of [[Japan (band)|Japan]] in the band [[Dalis Car]] before going solo with such albums as 1988's ''[[Love Hysteria]]'' and 1989's ''[[Deep (album)|Deep]]''. Daniel Ash had already started [[Tones on Tail]] with Bauhaus roadie Glen Campling as a side-project in 1981; after Bauhaus broke up Kevin Haskins joined the group, which released an album and several EPs before breaking up following a 1984 American tour.&lt;ref name=&quot;RS&quot;&gt;{{cite web |url=http://www.rollingstone.com/music/artists/bauhaus/biography |title=Bauhaus |work=rollingstone.com |accessdate=24 February 2012}}&lt;/ref&gt; During this time David J released two solo albums and collaborated with other musicians, recording two albums with [[The Jazz Butcher]], and also with comics writer/spoken-word artist [[Alan Moore]] in the short-lived band The Sinister Ducks.

During a discussion about the state of their projects at the time, Ash and David J began talking about reforming Bauhaus. All four band members arranged a rehearsal, but Murphy failed to show up the day it was scheduled. The other three band members rehearsed regardless, and were inspired by the chemistry they had as a trio. As a result, Ash and the Haskins brothers formed [[Love and Rockets (band)|Love and Rockets]] in 1985.&lt;ref&gt;Shirley, pp. 113–14&lt;/ref&gt; Love and Rockets scored a US hit four years later with &quot;[[So Alive (Love and Rockets song)|So Alive]]&quot;. The band broke up after seven albums in 1999. Both Daniel Ash and David J released solo albums during the Love and Rockets years; Peter Murphy contributed backing vocals to David J's 1992 single &quot;Candy on the Cross&quot;.

=== Reunions ===

Bauhaus reunited for the &quot;Resurrection Tour&quot; in 1998, which featured a new song, &quot;The Dog's a Vapour&quot;, which was also included in the soundtrack for the film ''[[Heavy Metal 2000]]''. A [[live album]] recorded during the tour, ''[[Gotham (album)|Gotham]]'', was released the following year and included a studio recording of the [[Dead Can Dance]] song &quot;Severance&quot;.

Bauhaus reunited again in 2005, playing that year's [[Coachella Valley Music and Arts Festival]] in [[Indio, California|Indio]], [[California]]. At the opening of their set, Peter Murphy was lowered to the stage upside-down singing &quot;Bela Lugosi's Dead&quot;. Following Peter Murphy's 2005 tour, Bauhaus embarked on a full tour beginning in [[North America]] and [[Mexico]] in the autumn of 2005 and ending in [[Europe]] in February 2006. The band also mentioned that they hoped to record new music following the tour. In May 2006 the band toured with [[Nine Inch Nails]] on the summer leg of their tour.

Bauhaus released their first new studio album since 1983, ''[[Go Away White]]'', in 2008. This marked the end of the band and there was no supporting tour. Drummer Kevin Haskins said in an interview that they &quot;were getting along really well, but there was an incident that occurred&quot;. As a result, &quot;some of us just felt that we didn't want to carry on as a working unit&quot;.&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web |url=http://www.billboard.com/bbcom/news/article_display.jsp?vnu_content_id=1003680868#/bbcom/news/article_display.jsp?vnu_content_id=1003680868 |title=Bauhaus Bowing Out With New Album |work=Billboard.com |accessdate=24 February 2012}}&lt;/ref&gt; In an interview with [[SuicideGirls]], bassist David J said about the breakup: &quot;You have a test tube, and you pour in one chemical, and you pour in another chemical, and something happens. It starts to bubble. Pour in another chemical, and it starts to bubble a bit more. You pour in a fourth chemical, and it bubbles really violently, and then explodes. That's my answer&quot;.&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web |url=http://suicidegirls.com/interviews/David+J+of+Bauhaus/ |title=David J of Bauhaus |author=Jay Hathaway |date=14 March 2008 |work=[[SuicideGirls]] |accessdate=24 February 2012}}&lt;/ref&gt; Peter Murphy claimed in another interview that he &quot;was most satisfied with the bonding on an emotional level. It was good to be working together and to put the past behind us and it was very positive. The result was coming out really fast, so it was exciting and it was very enjoyable&quot;, but in the end &quot;that rocky character worked and I think it was a bit right to finish it, really.&quot;&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web |url=http://www.postwave.gr/index.php?option=com_content&amp;task=view&amp;id=794&amp;Itemid=10&amp;limit=1&amp;limitstart=1 |title=Peter Murphy (Bauhaus) - exclusive interview! |author=V. Giannakopoulos |date=25 February 2008 |work=Postwave.gr |accessdate=24 February 2012}}&lt;/ref&gt;

== Musical style ==

Bauhaus combined a number of influences including [[Punk rock|punk]] music, [[glam rock]], and [[Krautrock]]—even [[funk]] and [[dub music|dub]]—to create a gloomy and introspective sound which appealed to many fans left disillusioned by the [[New Wave music|New Wave]] that arose in the wake of punk's collapse. Their sound proved influential and inspiring to a whole wave of [[post-punk]] groups delving into the intense, gloomy style that would eventually come to be known as [[gothic rock]]. Its crucial elements included Peter Murphy's deep and sonorous voice, Daniel Ash's innovative guitar playing, and David J's dub-influenced bass.

==Former members==
;Final lineup
* [[Peter Murphy (musician)|Peter Murphy]] - lead vocals &lt;small&gt;(1978–1983, 1998, 2005–2008)&lt;/small&gt;
* [[Daniel Ash]] - lead guitars &lt;small&gt;(1978–1983, 1998, 2005–2008)&lt;/small&gt;
* [[Kevin Haskins]] - drums &lt;small&gt;(1978–1983, 1998, 2005–2008)&lt;/small&gt;
* [[David J]] - bass guitars &lt;small&gt;(1978–1983, 1998, 2005–2008)&lt;/small&gt;

;Earlier members
* Chris Barber - bass guitars &lt;small&gt;(1978)&lt;/small&gt;

      <text xml:space="preserve">{{Use dmy dates|date=December 2010}}
{{Infobox person
|image = LeslieNielsenOct08-replacement.jpg
|caption = Nielsen in October 2008
|birth_name = Leslie William Nielsen
|birth_date = {{birth date|df=yes|1926|2|11}}
|birth_place = [[Regina, Saskatchewan]], Canada
|death_date = {{death date and age|df=yes|2010|11|28|1926|2|11}}
|death_place = [[Fort Lauderdale, Florida]], United States
|death_cause = [[Pneumonia]]
|resting_place = Evergreen Cemetery, Fort Lauderdale
|occupation = Actor
|notable_works = ''[[Forbidden Planet]]''&lt;br&gt; ''[[The Poseidon Adventure (1972 film)|The Poseidon Adventure]]''&lt;br&gt;''[[Airplane!]]''&lt;br&gt;''[[The Naked Gun]]''
|citizenship = Canadian&lt;br&gt;American
|education = [[Victoria School of Performing and Visual Arts|Victoria Composite High School]]
|alma_mater = [[Lorne Greene]] Academy of Radio Arts, Toronto
|years_active = 1948–2010
|relatives = [[Erik Nielsen]] (brother)&lt;br&gt;[[Jean Hersholt]] (half-uncle)
|spouse = [[Monica Boyar]] &lt;small&gt;(1950–1956)&lt;/small&gt;&lt;br&gt;Alisande Ullman &lt;small&gt;(1958–1973)&lt;/small&gt;&lt;br&gt;Brooks Oliver &lt;small&gt;(1981–1983)&lt;/small&gt;&lt;br&gt;Barbaree Earl &lt;small&gt;(2001–2010)&lt;/small&gt;
|signature = LeslieNielsen.png
}}
'''Leslie William Nielsen''', [[Order of Canada|OC]] (11 February 1926{{spaced ndash}}28 November 2010)&lt;ref name=&quot;TorStar&quot;&gt;{{cite news|last=Dalton|first=Andrew|title=Leslie Nielsen of 'Naked Gun' fame dies at age 84|work=[[Toronto Star]]|url=http://www.thestar.com/entertainment/movies/article/898202--leslie-nielsen-of-naked-gun-fame-dies-at-age-84?bn=1|date=28 November 2010|archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5ue0dA3CC|archivedate=1 December 2010}}&lt;/ref&gt; was a Canadian and naturalized American actor and comedian.&lt;ref name=&quot;Record&quot;&gt;{{cite news|title=Comedian returning home to host fundraiser|work=[[The Record (Sherbrooke)|The Record]]|url=http://www.royalcityrecord.com/issues05/063205/news/063205nn4.html|archiveurl=http://web.archive.org/web/20060825082417/http://www.royalcityrecord.com/issues05/063205/news/063205nn4.html|archivedate=25 August 2006|date=16 June 2005|accessdate=23 February 2009}}&lt;/ref&gt;&lt;ref&gt;&quot;I played a lot of leaders, autocratic sorts; perhaps it was my Canadian accent&quot;, he said.&quot; – http://topnews360.tmcnet.com/topics/associated-press/articles/2010/12/02/122613-naked-gun-airplane-actor-leslie-nielsen-dies.htm&lt;/ref&gt; Nielsen appeared in more than one hundred films and 1,500 television programs over the span of his career, portraying more than 220 characters.&lt;ref name=&quot;Roles1500&quot;&gt;{{cite news|last=Collins|first=Glenn|title=Mr. Nondescript Becomes a Star in 'Naked Gun'|work=[[The New York Times]]|url=http://www.nytimes.com/1988/12/21/movies/mr-nondescript-becomes-a-star-in-naked-gun.html|date=21 December 1988|archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5ue0qJ8Jw|archivedate=1 December 2010}}&lt;/ref&gt; Born in [[Regina, Saskatchewan|Regina]], [[Saskatchewan]], [[Canada]], Nielsen enlisted in the [[Royal Canadian Air Force]] and worked as a disc jockey before receiving a scholarship to [[Neighborhood Playhouse]]. Making his television debut in 1948, he quickly expanded to over 50 television appearances two years later. Nielsen made his film debut in 1956, and began collecting his roles in [[Drama film|dramas]], [[Western (genre)|westerns]], and [[romance film]]s between the 1950s and the 1970s. Nielsen's performance in the films ''[[Forbidden Planet]]'' and ''[[The Poseidon Adventure (1972 film)|The Poseidon Adventure]]'' received positive reviews as a serious actor, although he is primarily known for his comedic roles during the 1980s and the early 1990s.

Although Nielsen's acting career crossed a variety of genres in both television and films, his deadpan delivery in ''[[Airplane!]]'' marked a turning point in his career, one that would make him, in the words of film critic [[Roger Ebert]], &quot;the [[Laurence Olivier|Olivier]] of spoofs.&quot;&lt;ref name=&quot;Ebert&quot;&gt;{{cite news|last=Ebert|first=Roger|authorlink=Roger Ebert|title=Scary Movie 3|work=[[Chicago Sun-Times]]|url=http://rogerebert.suntimes.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20031024/REVIEWS/310240305/1023|date=24 October 2003|archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5ue0sIuNQ|archivedate=1 December 2010}}&lt;/ref&gt; Nielsen enjoyed further success with [[The Naked Gun|''The Naked Gun'' film series]], based on an earlier short-lived television series ''[[Police Squad!]]'' in which he also starred. Nielsen's portrayal of comedic characters seemingly oblivious to (and complicit in) their absurd surroundings gave him a reputation as a comedian.&lt;ref name=&quot;NYT&quot;&gt;{{cite news|last=Maslin|first=Janet|title=Review/Film; A Fall Guy as Antihero|work=The New York Times|url=http://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=940DE3DE153DF931A35751C1A96E948260|date=2 December 1988|archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5ue0vHQMY|archivedate=1 December 2010}}&lt;/ref&gt; In the final years of his life, Nielsen appeared in numerous spoof and parody films, many of which were met poorly by critics, but performed well in box office and home media releases. Nielsen married four times and had two daughters from his second marriage. Nielsen was recognized with a variety of awards throughout his career, and was inducted into the [[Canada's Walk of Fame|Canada]] and [[Hollywood Walk of Fame|Hollywood]] Walks of Fame.

==Early life==
[[File:HersholtBrotherswife.jpg|thumb|230px|left|Nielsen's uncle [[Jean Hersholt]] (pictured here in the 1936 film ''His Brother's Wife'') inspired him to become an actor.]]
Nielsen was born on 11 February 1926 in [[Regina, Saskatchewan]].&lt;ref name=&quot;ComedyCloset&quot;&gt;{{cite news|last=Ross|first=Bob|title=Worth the Rent|work=[[The Tampa Tribune]]|date=24 May 1996|url=http://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/tampatribune/access/38300832.html?dids=38300832:38300832&amp;FMT=ABS&amp;FMTS=ABS:FT&amp;type=current&amp;date=May+24%2C+1996&amp;author=Bob+Ross&amp;pub=Tampa+Tribune&amp;desc=WORTH+THE+RENT&amp;pqatl=google|format=Fee required|accessdate=28 November 2010}}&lt;/ref&gt; His mother, Mabel Elizabeth (née Davies), was a [[Canadians of Welsh descent|Welsh]] immigrant, and his father, Ingvard Eversen Nielsen, was a [[Canadians of Danish descent|Danish]]-born Constable in the [[Royal Canadian Mounted Police]].&lt;ref name=eofy&gt;{{Cite book|last=Simpson|first=Kieran|title=Canadian Who's Who, Volume 15|publisher=University of Toronto Press|year=1980|location=|pages=736|month=|isbn=0-8020-4579-0}}&lt;/ref&gt;&lt;ref name=&quot;CanadianWho&quot;&gt;{{cite book|title=Canadian Who's Who 2003, Volume 38|author=Lumley, Elizabeth|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=aNuphN-Vh_oC&amp;lpg=PA1013&amp;ots=AJTSeqBeRs&amp;dq=Ingvard%20and%20Maybelle%20Nielsen&amp;pg=PA1013#v=onepage&amp;q=&amp;f=false|publisher=University of Toronto Press|year=2003|isbn=0-8020-8865-1|page=1,103}}&lt;/ref&gt;&lt;ref name=&quot;DanWal&quot;&gt;{{cite news|title=Leslie Nielsen, the comic with the Danish roots: &quot;Comedy is what endures&quot;|work=Scandinavian Press|url=http://libproxy.sdsu.edu/login?url=http://proquest.umi.com.libproxy.sdsu.edu/pqdweb?did=494375361&amp;sid=3&amp;Fmt=3&amp;clientId=17862&amp;RQT=309&amp;VName=PQD|date=31 March 1997|volume=4|issue=1|format=Registration required; Proquest Document ID: 494375361|accessdate=16 December 2009}}&lt;/ref&gt;

Nielsen had two brothers; his older brother, [[Erik Nielsen]] (1924–2008), was [[Deputy Prime Minister of Canada]] from 1984 to 1986.&lt;ref&gt;{{cite news|title=Erik Nielsen dies at B.C. at 84|url=http://www.theglobeandmail.com/servlet/story/RTGAM.20080905.wobitnielsen0905/BNStory/National/home|date=5 September 2008|work=[[The Globe and Mail]]|archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5ue10NK1X|archivedate=1 December 2010|location=Toronto}}&lt;/ref&gt; Ingvard was a troubled man who beat his wife and sons, and Leslie longed to escape. As soon as he graduated from high school at 17, he joined the Royal Canadian Air Force, even though he was legally deaf (he wore hearing aids most of his life).&lt;ref&gt;[http://greencardguide.info/2010/12/01/naked-gun-airplane-actor-leslie-nielsen-dies Biodata about Nielsen's abusive father]&lt;/ref&gt;&lt;ref name=&quot;Shirley&quot;&gt;{{cite news|agency=[[Associated Press]]|title=Leslie Nielsen, RIP. &quot;And don't call me Shirley&quot;|work=[[Chicago Sun-Times]]|date=29 November 2010|url=http://blogs.suntimes.com/ebert/people/leslie-nielsen-rip-and-dont-ca.html|archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5ue1DBA3P|archivedate=1 December 2010}}&lt;/ref&gt;

His half-uncle, [[Jean Hersholt]], was an actor best known for his portrayal of [[Dr. Christian]] in the long-running radio series of the same name and the subsequent television series and films.&lt;ref name=&quot;nielsen1994&quot;/&gt;&lt;ref name=ote&gt;{{Cite book|last=Nielsen|first=Leslie|coauthors=David Fisher|title=Leslie Nielsen the naked truth|publisher=Pocket Books|year=1994|pages=289|month=|url=|isbn=0-671-79578-3}}&lt;/ref&gt; In a 1994 ''[[The Boston Globe|Boston Globe]]'' article, Nielsen explained, &quot;I did learn very early that when I would mention my uncle, people would look at me as if I were the biggest liar in the world. Then I would take them home and show them 8-by-10 glossies, and things changed quite drastically. So I began to think that maybe this acting business was not a bad idea, much as I was very shy about it and certainly without courage regarding it. My uncle died not too long after I was in a position to know him. I regret that I had not a chance to know him better.&quot;&lt;ref name=&quot;nielsen1994&quot;/&gt;

Nielsen spent several years living in [[Tulita|Fort Norman]] (now Tulita), [[Northwest Territories]] where his father was stationed with the [[Royal Canadian Mounted Police]].&lt;ref name=&quot;nielsen1994&quot;&gt;{{cite news|last=Carr|first=Jay|title=If Leslie Nielsen has learned anything, it's how to play slapstick with a ... straight face|url=http://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/boston/access/61932233.html?dids=61932233:61932233&amp;FMT=ABS&amp;FMTS=ABS:FT&amp;type=current&amp;date=Mar+13%2C+1994&amp;author=Jay+Carr%2C+Globe+Staff&amp;pub=Boston+Globe+%28pre-1997+Fulltext%29&amp;desc=If+Leslie+Nielsen+has+learned+anything%2C+it%27s+how+to+play+slapstick+with+a.+.+.+straight+face&amp;pqatl=google|format=Fee required|work=The Boston Globe|date=13 March 1994|accessdate=1 December 2010}}&lt;/ref&gt;&lt;ref name=&quot;PlayingDefense&quot;&gt;{{cite news|title=Playing Defense Funny Man Turns Serious with One-man Darrow Show|work=Chicago Tribune|date=30 January 2000|url=http://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/chicagotribune/access/48598094.html?dids=48598094:48598094&amp;FMT=ABS&amp;FMTS=ABS:FT&amp;date=Jan+30%2C+2000&amp;author=Judy+Hevrdejs+Contributing%3A+Kaarin+Tisue%2C+Gary+Dretzka&amp;pub=Chicago+Tribune&amp;desc=PLAYING+DEFENSE+FUNNY+MAN+TURNS+SERIOUS+WITH+ONE-MAN+DARROW+SHOW&amp;pqatl=google|format=Fee required|accessdate=1 December 2010}}&lt;/ref&gt; At the age of 17, following his graduation from [[Victoria School of Performing and Visual Arts|Victoria Composite High School]] in [[Edmonton]], Nielsen enlisted in the [[Royal Canadian Air Force]] and was trained as an aerial gunner during the latter part of World War II (but was too young to be fully trained or sent overseas).&lt;ref name=&quot;NoJokeDrama&quot;&gt;{{cite news|agency=[[Reuters]]|title=No Joke! Nielsen in Drama|work=[[Rocky Mountain News]]|date=14 June 1996|url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-67786375.html|format=Registration required|accessdate=1 December 2010}}&lt;/ref&gt; He worked briefly as a disc jockey at a Calgary, Alberta radio station, before enrolling at the [[Lorne Greene]] Academy of Radio Arts, Toronto.&lt;ref name=&quot;nielsen1994&quot;/&gt;&lt;ref name=&quot;NoSeriouslyNobody&quot;&gt;{{cite news|last=Churchill|first=Bonnie|title=Leslie Nielsen Doesn't Take Himself Seriously, Nor Does Anyone Else|work=[[St. Louis Post-Dispatch]]|date=20 December 1997|url=http://nl.newsbank.com/nl-search/we/Archives?p_product=SL&amp;p_theme=sl&amp;p_action=search&amp;p_maxdocs=200&amp;p_topdoc=1&amp;p_text_direct-0=0EB050AC86F77B7D&amp;p_field_direct-0=document_id&amp;p_perpage=10&amp;p_sort=YMD_date:D&amp;s_trackval=GooglePM|format=Fee required|accessdate=1 December 2010}}&lt;/ref&gt; While studying in Toronto, Nielsen received a scholarship to the [[Neighborhood Playhouse]]. He noted, &quot;I couldn't refuse, but I must say when you come from the land of the snow goose, the moose and wool to New York, you're bringing every ton of hayseed and country bumpkin that you packed. As long as I didn't open my mouth, I felt a certain security. But I always thought I was going to be unmasked: 'OK, pack your stuff.' 'Well, what's the matter?' 'We've discovered you have no talent; we're shipping you back to Canada.'&quot;&lt;ref name=&quot;nielsen1994&quot;/&gt; He moved to New York City for his scholarship,&lt;ref name=&quot;ComedyCloset&quot;/&gt; studying theater and music at the Neighborhood Playhouse, while performing in [[summer stock theatre]].&lt;ref&gt;{{cite news|title=These New Faces Will Go Places in 1957!|work=[[Chicago Tribune]]|
author=Hopper, Hedda|date=6 January 1957|page=H16}}&lt;/ref&gt; Afterward, he attended the [[Actors Studio]],&lt;ref name=&quot;starsatwar&quot;&gt;{{cite book|title=International Stars at War|first1=James E. Jr.|last1=Wise|author1-link=James E. Wise, Jr.|first2=Scott|last2=Baron|author2-link=Scott Baron|location=Annapolis, MD|publisher=Naval Institute Press|year=2002|isbn=1-55750-965-4|page=221}}&lt;/ref&gt; until making his first television appearance in 1948 on an episode of ''[[Westinghouse Studio One|Studio One]]'', alongside [[Charlton Heston]],&lt;ref name=&quot;ShyAct&quot;&gt;{{cite news|last=Arnold|first=William|url=http://www.seattlepi.com/archives/1988/8802020770.asp|title=Shy actor loves his life as a comic|work=[[Seattle Post-Intelligencer]]|date=6 December 1988|archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5ue1WOp7h|archivedate=1 December 2010}}&lt;/ref&gt; for which he was paid US$75.&lt;ref name=&quot;nielsen1994&quot;/&gt;

==Career==
===Early career===
{{quote box|align=right|quote=&quot;It was a strange era, the tail end of the golden age. A time when the Tiffany's of filmmakers was burying its head in the sand and trying to pretend that this new medium (television) was not happening.&quot;|width=30em|source=Nielsen reflecting on the era when he started acting.&lt;ref name=&quot;ShyAct&quot;/&gt;}}
Nielsen's career began in dramatic roles on television during what is known as &quot;[[Golden Age of Television|Television's Golden Age]]&quot;,&lt;ref&gt;{{cite news|last=Terry|first=Clifford|title=Gunning for a Laugh|url=http://articles.sun-sentinel.com/1991-07-07/features/9101240994_1_drebin-police-squad-leslie-nielsen|date=7 July 1991|work=[[South Florida Sun-Sentinel|Sun-Sentinel]]|archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5ue1ptsdL|archivedate=1 December 2010}}&lt;/ref&gt; appearing in almost 50 live programs in 1950 alone.&lt;ref name=&quot;CBS&quot;/&gt; Nielsen reported that for his salary that there &quot;{{interp|...}} was very little gold, we only got $75 or $100 per show.&quot;&lt;ref name=&quot;CBS&quot;&gt;{{cite web|title=Leslie Nielsen|work=CBS|url=http://www.cbs.com/primetime/game_show_marathon/bios/leslie_bio.shtml|archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5ue1sETG0|archivedate=1 December 2010}}&lt;/ref&gt; His distinctive voice narrated several documentaries and commercials but, with a handful of exceptions, his early work as a dramatic actor was uneventful.&lt;ref name=&quot;AMG&quot;/&gt; Hal Erickson of [[AllRovi#History|Allmovie]] noted, &quot;...much of Nielsen's early work was undistinguished; he was merely a handsome leading man in an industry overstocked with handsome leading men.&quot;&lt;ref name=&quot;AMG&quot;&gt;{{cite web|last=Erickson|first=Hal|title=Biography|publisher=[[AllRovi#History|Allmovie]]|url=http://www.allmovie.com/cg/avg.dll?p=avg&amp;sql=2:52664~T1|archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5ue1vTzka|archivedate=1 December 2010}}&lt;/ref&gt; In 1956 he made his feature film debut in the [[Michael Curtiz]]-directed musical film ''[[The Vagabond King (1956 film)|The Vagabond King]]''.&lt;ref&gt;{{cite news|last=Thomas|first=Bob|title=Nielsen is Serious About Comic Side|work=[[Times Union (Albany)|The Times Union]]|url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-156673536.html|format=Registration required|date=9 September 1993|accessdate=1 December 2010}}&lt;/ref&gt; In the ''[[Seattle Post-Intelligencer]]'', Nielsen pointed out that he remembers Curtiz as &quot;a sadist, a charming sadist, but a sadist&quot;.&lt;ref name=&quot;ShyAct&quot;/&gt; Nielsen would go on to call this film &quot;The Vagabond Turkey&quot;.&lt;ref&gt;{{cite news|first=Andrew|last=Dalton|first2=Bob|last2=Thomas|url=http://www.boston.com/ae/celebrity/articles/2010/11/29/leslie_nielsen_84_versatile_actors_career_took_off_with_comedies/?p1=News_links |title=Leslie Nielsen, 84; versatile actor’s career took off with comedies|work=The Boston Globe|date=29 November 2010|archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5ue251Z2N |archivedate=1 December 2010}}&lt;/ref&gt; Though the film was not a box office success, Nielsen caught the eye of producer [[Nicholas Nayfack]] who offered him an audition for a role in the science fiction film ''[[Forbidden Planet]]'', resulting in Nielsen being signed to a long-term contract by [[Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer]] (MGM).&lt;ref name=&quot;ShyAct&quot;/&gt;&lt;ref&gt;{{cite news|last=Thomas|first=Bob|title=The Naked Gun 2½: The Smell of Fear – Funnyman Nielsen Used to be Serious|work=[[The Cincinnati Post]]|date=28 June 1991|page=1C}}&lt;/ref&gt;

[[File:ForbiddenPlanet1.jpg|thumb|right|350px|Nielsen, along with co-star [[Anne Francis]], in his second film, ''[[Forbidden Planet]]'' (1956). Nielsen: &quot;Supposedly a science fiction version of [[William Shakespeare|Shakespeare]]'s ''[[The Tempest]]'', it was all about the [[Id, ego and super-ego|id]], or something like that. Who knows? The [[Trekkie]]s today regard it as the forerunner of ''[[Star Trek]]''. I just had to wear a tight uniform and make eyes at Anne Francis. I was pretty thin back then.&quot;&lt;ref&gt;{{cite news|last=Vincent|first=Mal|title=It's no Fun Playing it Straight|work=[[The Virginian-Pilot]]|url=http://nl.newsbank.com/nl-search/we/Archives?p_product=VP&amp;p_theme=vp&amp;p_action=search&amp;p_maxdocs=200&amp;p_topdoc=1&amp;p_text_direct-0=0EAFF73225441804&amp;p_field_direct-0=document_id&amp;p_perpage=10&amp;p_sort=YMD_date:D&amp;s_trackval=GooglePM|format=Fee required|date=18 March 1994|accessdate=1 December 2010}}&lt;/ref&gt;]]
''Forbidden Planet'' became an instant success,&lt;ref name=&quot;RTForbidden&quot;&gt;{{cite web|title=Forbidden Planet (1956)|work=[[Rotten Tomatoes]]|url=http://www.rottentomatoes.com/m/forbidden_planet/|accessdate=23 February 2009}}&lt;/ref&gt; and roles in other MGM films such as ''[[Ransom!]]'' (1956), ''[[The Opposite Sex]]'' (1956) and ''[[Hot Summer Night (1957 film)|Hot Summer Night]]'' (1957) followed.&lt;ref&gt;{{cite news|title=From Drebin to Darrow|work=[[The Pantagraph]]|author=Craft, Dan|date=24 September 1999|page=D1}}&lt;/ref&gt; In 1957 he won the lead role opposite [[Debbie Reynolds]] in the [[Romantic comedy film|romantic comedy]] ''[[Tammy and the Bachelor]]'', which, as a ''[[Chicago Tribune]]'' critic wrote in 1998, made people consider Nielsen as both a dramatic actor and a handsome romantic lead.&lt;ref&gt;{{cite news|title=Nielsen Still Kicking in `Wrongfully Accused'|work=[[Chicago Tribune]]|date=24 August 1998|author=Petrakis, John|page=2}}&lt;/ref&gt; However, dissatisfied with the quality of the films he was offered, calling the studios &quot;{{interp|..}} a Tiffany, which had forgotten how to make silver&quot;, Nielsen left MGM, but not before auditioning for the role of Messala in the 1959 historical piece ''[[Ben-Hur (1959 film)|Ben-Hur]]''. [[Stephen Boyd]] was eventually given the role.&lt;ref&gt;{{cite news|title=Leslie Nielsen comes home for CBC's 50th – Veteran actor and comedian is the host of comedy special|work=[[Toronto Star]]|date=18 August 2002|author=Bawden, Jim|page=D3}}&lt;/ref&gt;&lt;ref name=&quot;BenHur&quot;&gt;{{cite news|last=Clark|first=Mike|title=New on DVD|work=[[USA Today]]|date=15 September 2005|url=http://www.usatoday.com/life/movies/reviews/2005-09-15-new-on-dvd_x.htm|archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5ue2LTkQJ|archivedate=1 December 2010http}}&lt;/ref&gt; After leaving the studios, Nielsen landed the lead role in the [[The Walt Disney Company|Disney]] miniseries ''[[The Swamp Fox (TV series)|The Swamp Fox]]'', as [[American Revolutionary War]] hero [[Francis Marion]].&lt;ref name=&quot;SwampFox&quot;/&gt; In a 1988 interview he reflected on the series, stating, &quot;That was a great experience, because the Disney people didn't do their shows like everyone else, knocking out an episode a week. {{interp|...}} We only had to do an episode a month, and the budgets were extremely high for TV at that time. We had location shooting rather than cheap studio backdrops, and very authentic costumes.&quot;&lt;ref&gt;{{cite news|title=Nielsen Makes the `First String' in Films|work=[[The Post-Standard]]|date=12 December 1988|author=Brode, Doug|page=D10}}&lt;/ref&gt; Eight episodes were produced and aired between 1959 and 1961.&lt;ref name=&quot;SwampFox&quot;&gt;{{cite news|title=Stargazing answers your questions; 'The Swamp Fox'; 'Silent Night, Lonely Night'|work=[[The Kansas City Star]]|date=9 December 2009|last=Wahl|first=Ken|page=D12}}&lt;/ref&gt;

His television appearances include parts in ''[[Justice (1954 TV series)|Justice]]'', ''[[Alfred Hitchcock Presents]]'', ''[[The Virginian (TV series)|The Virginian]]'', and ''[[The Wild Wild West]]''. In 1961, he was the lead in a taut Los Angeles police drama called ''[[The New Breed (TV series)|The New Breed]]''. He guest starred in a 1964 episode of ''[[Daniel Boone (TV series)|Daniel Boone]]'' with [[Fess Parker]] and, in a minor but credited role, [[Jay Silverheels]]. In 1968, he had a major role in the pilot film for the popular police series ''[[Hawaii Five-O]]'', and later appeared in one of the seventh season episodes. In 1969, he had the leading role as a police officer in ''[[The Bold Ones: The Protectors]]''.

In 1972, Nielsen appeared as the ship's captain in the all-star disaster epic ''[[The Poseidon Adventure (1972 film)|The Poseidon Adventure]]''. He also starred in the [[William Girdler]]-directed 1977 action film ''Project: Kill''. His last dramatic role before portraying mainly comedy roles was the 1979 Canadian disaster film ''[[City on Fire (1979 film)|City on Fire]]'' in which he played a corrupt mayor. In 1980, he guest starred as Sinclair on the [[CBS]] [[miniseries]] ''[[The Chisholms]]''.

===''Airplane!'' and ''The Naked Gun''===
{{Main|Airplane!|The Naked Gun}}
Nielsen's supporting role in 1980's ''[[Airplane!]]'' was a major watershed in his career. The ethos of the movie, a parody of dramatic disaster films such as ''[[Zero Hour!]]'' and ''[[Airport (1970 film)|Airport]]'', is largely based on building a comedy around actors who were then known exclusively for their dramatic roles (other stars included [[Robert Stack]], [[Peter Graves]], and [[Lloyd Bridges]]). Nielsen was the movie's linchpin, his deadpan delivery contrasting with the continual absurdity surrounding him. When asked, &quot;Surely you can't be serious?&quot;, he responds with a curt, &quot;I am serious. And don't call me Shirley.&quot; In several interviews he later reflected on the significance of the comedic line: &quot;I thought it was amusing, but it never occurred to me that it was going to become a trademark. It's such a surprise...the thing comes out, people say, 'What did he say?!'&quot;&lt;ref name=&quot;KJZZ&quot;&gt;{{cite web|title=Leslie Nielsen Interview (Radio)|publisher=KJZZ 91.5 FM|url=http://kjzz.org/news/arizona/archives/200402/leslieneilsen|archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5ufWDXbYT|archivedate=2 December 2010}}&lt;/ref&gt; Nielsen also stated that he was &quot;...pleased and honored that [he] had a chance to deliver that line.&quot;&lt;ref name=&quot;YahooNe&quot;/&gt; The comedic exchange was at #79 on the [[American Film Institute]]'s [[AFI's 100 Years...100 Movie Quotes]].&lt;ref name=&quot;AFI&quot;&gt;{{cite web|title=AFI.com|work=AFI's 100 Years...100 Movie Quotes|url=http://www.afi.com/100years/quotes.aspx|archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5ufWPg4p0|archivedate=2 December 2010}}&lt;/ref&gt; The American Film Institute also included the film in its list of the top ten comedy films of all time.&lt;ref name=&quot;MIL&quot;&gt;{{cite news|last=Dudek|first=Duane|title=25 years and still laughing; Airplane!' maintains its cruising|work=[[Milwaukee Journal Sentinel]]| url=http://www.jsonline.com/story/index.aspx?id=332493|accessdate=23 February 2009|archiveurl=http://web.archive.org/web/20080430053901/http://www.jsonline.com/story/index.aspx?id=332493|archivedate=30 April 2008}}&lt;/ref&gt;

[[File:Leslie Nielsen.jpg|thumb|right|Nielsen in 1982]]
Critics praised the film, which also proved to be a success with audiences.&lt;ref name=&quot;RT1&quot;&gt;{{cite web|title=Airplane! (1980)| work=[[Rotten Tomatoes]]|url=http://www.rottentomatoes.com/m/airplane/|accessdate=23 February 2009}}&lt;/ref&gt; The film's directors, [[Jim Abrahams]], [[David Zucker (filmmaker)|David Zucker]], and [[Jerry Zucker (film director)|Jerry Zucker]], chose Nielsen for the role based on his ability to play &quot;a fish in water&quot;, stating that &quot;You could have cast funny people and done it with everybody winking, goofing off, and silly...we wanted people to be oblivious to the comedy.&quot;&lt;ref name=&quot;MIL&quot;/&gt; For Nielsen, ''Airplane!'' marked a shift from dramatic roles to a new focus on [[deadpan|deadpan comedy]]. When it was suggested that his role in ''Airplane!'' was [[Typecasting (acting)|against type]], Nielsen protested that he had &quot;always been cast against type before,&quot; and that comedy was what he always really wanted to do.&lt;ref name=&quot;CastType&quot;&gt;{{cite news|last=Dalton|first=Andrew|last2=Thomas|first2=Bob|title='Airplane!', 'Forbidden Planet' actor Nielsen dies|work=[[The Monitor (Texas)|The Monitor]]|url=http://hosted.ap.org/dynamic/stories/U/US_OBIT_LESLIE_NIELSEN?SITE=TXMCA&amp;SECTION=HOME&amp;TEMPLATE=DEFAULT|archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5ufWUN5CO|archivedate=2 December 2010}}&lt;/ref&gt;

The directors, interested in the success of the new comedy, decided to bring a similar style of comedy to television, casting Nielsen in the lead role in their new series, ''[[Police Squad!]]''. The series introduced Nielsen as [[Frank Drebin]], the stereotypical police officer modeled after serious characters in earlier police TV series.

''Police Squad'''s opening sequence was based on the 1950s cop show ''[[M Squad]]'', (which starred [[Lee Marvin]]), which opened with footage of a [[police car]] roving through an after-dark urban setting with a big band playing a jazz theme song in the background. The voice-over and the show's organization into &quot;acts&quot; with an epilogue was homage to [[Quinn Martin]] police dramas including ''[[The Fugitive (TV series)|The Fugitive]]'', ''[[The Streets of San Francisco]]'', ''[[Barnaby Jones]]'', ''[[The F.B.I. (TV series)|The F.B.I.]]'', and ''[[Cannon (TV series)|Cannon]]''. Much like in ''Airplane!'', Nielsen portrayed a serious character whose one-liners appeared accidental next to the pratfalls and sight gags around him. Although the show was quickly canceled, lasting only six episodes after being juggled between time slots, Nielsen received an ''[[Emmy Award]]''&lt;ref&gt;[http://www.emmys.com/celebrities/leslie-nielsen Leslie Nielsen Emmy Award Winner]&lt;/ref&gt; nomination for [[Primetime Emmy Award for Outstanding Lead Actor in a Comedy Series|Outstanding Lead Actor in a Comedy Series]].&lt;ref name=&quot;BIO&quot;&gt;{{cite web|title=Leslie Nielsen|publisher=[[The Biography Channel]]|url=http://www.thebiographychannel.co.uk/biography_story/150:519/1/Leslie_Nielsen.htm|archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5ufWoKHlM|archivedate=2 December 2010}}&lt;/ref&gt;

Non-comedic roles included ''[[Prom Night (1980 film)|Prom Night]]'' (1980) and ''[[Creepshow]]'' (1982), both horror films. His last dramatic role was as Allen Green, a violent john killed in self-defense by [[Barbra Streisand]]'s prostitute character, Claudia Draper, in [[Martin Ritt]]'s courtroom drama ''[[Nuts (film)|Nuts]]'' (1987).

Six years after the cancellation of ''Police Squad!'', its directors decided to make a feature length version for theaters. Titled ''[[The Naked Gun: From the Files of Police Squad!]]''. The film returned Nielsen to his role as Frank Drebin. It involved a comical scheme of a ruthless drug kingpin using hypnosis in an attempt to assassinate Queen [[Elizabeth II]]. Drebin, like the doctor in ''Airplane!'', seemed unaware of the absurdity around him even when unintentionally contributing toward it. Nielsen later said in an interview that he had done many of his own stunts, &quot;You have an idea of how you're going to do something, and it's your vision... unless you do it, it really doesn't stand a chance.&quot;&lt;ref name=&quot;KJZZ&quot;/&gt; This movie grossed over $78&amp;nbsp;million at the box office and was well received by critics.&lt;ref name=&quot;MOJO&quot;&gt;{{cite web|title=The Naked Gun: From the Files of Police Squad!|work=[[Box Office Mojo]]|url=http://www.boxofficemojo.com/movies/?id=nakedgun.htm|accessdate=23 February 2009}}&lt;/ref&gt;&lt;ref name=&quot;RT2&quot;&gt;{{cite web|title=The Naked Gun – From the Files of Police Squad! (1988)|work=Rotten Tomatoes|url=http://www.rottentomatoes.com/m/naked_gun_from_the_files_of_police_squad/|accessdate=23 February 2009}}&lt;/ref&gt; Ebert's 3½–star review (out of four) noted, &quot;You laugh, and then you laugh at yourself for laughing.&quot;&lt;ref name=&quot;Ebert2&quot;&gt;{{cite news|last=Ebert|first=Roger|authorlink=Roger Ebert|title=The Naked Gun|work=[[Chicago Sun-Times]]|url=http://rogerebert.suntimes.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/19881202/REVIEWS/812020301/1023|date=12 December 1988|archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5ufWuzdHx|archivedate=2 December 2010}}&lt;/ref&gt;

''[[The Naked Gun]]'' spawned two sequels: ''[[The Naked Gun 2½: The Smell of Fear]]'' (1991) and ''[[Naked Gun 33⅓: The Final Insult]]'' (1994). ''Naked Gun 2½'' grossed more than the original, with $86,930,400, while ''Naked Gun 33⅓'' grossed $51,132,600 in receipts.&lt;ref name=&quot;MOJO2&quot;&gt;{{cite web|title=The Naked Gun 2½: The Smell of Fear|work=[[Box Office Mojo]]|url=http://www.boxofficemojo.com/movies/?id=thenakedgun2.htm|accessdate=23 February 2009}}&lt;/ref&gt;&lt;ref name=&quot;MOJO3&quot;&gt;{{cite web|title=The Naked Gun 33⅓: The Final Insult|work=[[Box Office Mojo]]|url=http://www.boxofficemojo.com/movies/?id=thenakedgun3.htm|accessdate=23 February 2009}}&lt;/ref&gt; Nielsen remained open to the prospects of acting in a fourth ''Naked Gun'' film, although he doubted that it would ever be produced—&quot;I don't think so,&quot; he said in 2005. &quot;If there hasn't been one by now, I doubt it. I think it would be wonderful.&quot;&lt;ref name=&quot;About&quot;&gt;{{cite news|last=Topel|first=Fred|title=Scary Movie 3|publisher=[[About.com]]|url=http://actionadventure.about.com/cs/weeklystories/a/aa102403.htm| archiveurl=http://web.archive.org/web/20051225060616/http://actionadventure.about.com/cs/weeklystories/a/aa102403.htm| archivedate=25 December 2005|accessdate=23 February 2009}}&lt;/ref&gt;

Nielsen briefly appeared on the World Wrestling Federation program in the summer of 1994 on ''[[WWE Raw|WWF Monday Night Raw]]''; capitalizing on his Frank Drebin character, Nielsen (and [[George Kennedy]]) were hired as &quot;super-sleuths&quot; to unravel the mystery of [[The Undertaker]] who had disappeared at January's [[Royal Rumble (1994)|Royal Rumble]] event. At [[SummerSlam (1994)|SummerSlam 1994]], in a ''Naked Gun'' parody, they were hot on the case (in fact, they were literally standing on a case). Although they did not actually find The Undertaker, the case had been closed (the literal case had been shut) and thus, they solved the mystery.&lt;ref name=wcrap&gt;{{cite book|title=Wrestlecrap: The Very Worst of Pro Wrestling|last=Baer|first=Randy |coauthors=R.D. Reynolds|publisher=ECW Press|year=2003|page=168|isbn=1-55022-584-7}}&lt;/ref&gt;

===Later comedies===
Nielsen attempted a variety of similar roles with none achieving the prominence of Frank Drebin. These films mostly emulated the style of ''[[The Naked Gun]]'' series with varying degrees of critical and commercial success: many were panned by critics and most performed poorly. In 1986, Nielsen played against recent type as a dramatic (and unsympathetic) character in the comedy, ''[[Soul Man (film)|Soul Man]]''. In 1990, Nielsen also appeared as a Frank Drebin-style character in a series of advertisements in the United Kingdom for [[Red Rock Cider]].

Although ''The Naked Gun'' series parodied police dramas in general, Nielsen's later parody films focused on specific targets. Critics panned ''[[Repossessed (film)|Repossessed]]'' (1990) and ''[[2001: A Space Travesty]]'' (2001), parodies of ''[[The Exorcist (film)|The Exorcist]]'' and ''[[2001: A Space Odyssey (film)|2001: A Space Odyssey]]'', respectively. Both films attempted the absurdist comedy Nielsen is recognized for, but were poorly received.&lt;ref name=&quot;RT5&quot;&gt;{{cite web|title=Repossessed|work=[[Rotten Tomatoes]]|url=http://www.rottentomatoes.com/m/repossessed/|accessdate=23 February 2009}}&lt;/ref&gt;&lt;ref name=&quot;RT6&quot;&gt;{{cite web|title=2001: A Space Travesty (2001)|work=[[Rotten Tomatoes]]|url=http://www.rottentomatoes.com/m/2001_a_space_travesty/|accessdate=23 February 2009}}&lt;/ref&gt; Even a leading role in a [[Mel Brooks]] comic horror parody, ''[[Dracula: Dead and Loving It]]'', failed to generate much box office excitement, although it did gain somewhat of a following on its later release to video. Both 1996's ''[[Spy Hard]]'' and 1998's ''[[Wrongfully Accused]]'', a parody of [[James Bond in film|James Bond films]] and ''[[The Fugitive (1993 film)|The Fugitive]]'', respectively, received more popularity on home video but were not well received by critics.&lt;ref name=&quot;RT3&quot;&gt;{{cite web|title=Spy Hard|work=[[Rotten Tomatoes]]|url=http://www.rottentomatoes.com/m/spy_hard/|accessdate=23 February 2009}}&lt;/ref&gt;&lt;ref name=&quot;RT4&quot;&gt;{{cite web|title=Wrongfully Accused|work=[[Rotten Tomatoes]]|url=http://www.rottentomatoes.com/m/wrongfully_accused/|accessdate=23 February 2009}}&lt;/ref&gt;

His attempt at children's comedies met with additional criticism. ''[[Surf Ninjas]]'' (1993) and ''[[Mr. Magoo (film)|Mr. Magoo]]'' (1997) faced scathing reviews. Several critics were disappointed that Nielsen's role in ''Surf Ninjas'' was only &quot;an extended cameo&quot; and film critic Chris Hicks recommended that viewers &quot;...avoid any comedy that features Leslie Nielsen outside of the ''Naked Gun'' series.&quot;&lt;ref name=&quot;Variety&quot;&gt;{{cite news|last=Kimmel|first=Daniel M.|title=Surf Ninjas|work=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]|url=http://www.variety.com/review/VE1117901158.html?categoryid=31&amp;cs=1&amp;query=daniel+and+kimmel&amp;display=daniel+kimmel|date=23 August 1993|archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5ufX4w1gj|archivedate=2 December 2010}}&lt;/ref&gt;&lt;ref name=&quot;DNews&quot;&gt;{{cite news|last=Hicks|first=Chris|title=Surf Ninjas|work=[[Deseret News]]|url=http://deseretnews.com/movies/view/1,1257,1780,00.html|date=26 August 1993|archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5ufX7wXAO|archivedate=2 December 2010}}&lt;/ref&gt; Jeff Miller of the ''[[Houston Chronicle]]'' panned ''Mr. Magoo'', a live action remake of the [[Mr. Magoo|1950s cartoon]], by saying, &quot;I'm supposed to suggest how the film might be better but I can't think of anything to say other than to make the film again.&quot;&lt;ref name=&quot;HChron&quot;&gt;{{cite news|last=Miller|first=Jeff|title=Looking for laughs? 'Magoo' loses its way|work=[[Houston Chronicle]]|url=http://www.chron.com/cgi-bin/auth/story/content/chronicle/ae/movies/reviews/1225magoo.html|archiveurl=http://web.archive.org/web/20080125230821/http://www.chron.com/cgi-bin/auth/story/content/chronicle/ae/movies/reviews/1225magoo.html|archivedate=25 January 2008|accessdate=23 February 2009}}&lt;/ref&gt;

Nielsen's first major slapstick success since ''[[The Naked Gun]]'' came in a supporting role in ''[[Scary Movie 3]]'' (2003). His appearance as President Harris proved popular enough for a second appearance in its sequel, ''[[Scary Movie 4]]'' (2006). This became the first time Nielsen reprised a character since his appearances as Frank Drebin. In one scene, Nielsen appeared almost fully [[Nudity|nude]], and one critic referred to the scene as putting &quot;the 'scary' in ''Scary Movie 4''.&quot;&lt;ref name=&quot;RVs&quot;&gt;{{cite news|last=Berardinelli|first=James|title=Scary Movie 4|publisher=ReelViews|url=http://www.reelviews.net/movies/s/scary_movie4.html|year=2006|archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5ufXByyQF|archivedate=2 December 2010}}&lt;/ref&gt;

Nielsen also hosted a series of instructional golf videos beginning with 1993's ''[[Bad Golf Made Easier]]''. The videos were not serious, instead combining absurdist comedy with golf techniques. The series were popular enough to spawn two additional sequels, ''[[Bad Golf My Way]]'' (1994) and ''[[Stupid Little Golf Video]]'' (1997). Nielsen also co-wrote a fictional autobiography titled [[The Naked Truth (novel)|''The Naked Truth'']]. The book portrayed Nielsen as a popular actor with a long history of prestigious films.

===Final years===
[[File:Leslie nielsen at moravian college.JPG|thumb|left|Leslie Nielsen in 2009 at [[DeSales University]] in [[Center Valley, Pennsylvania|Center Valley]], Pennsylvania.]]
Even in his eighties, Nielsen continued to have an active career. He performed serious roles on screen and stage (such as his one-man theatre show ''Darrow'', in which he played [[Clarence Darrow]]), as well as providing voice-overs and on-camera appearances for commercials; cartoons like ''[[Zeroman]]'' where he had the leading role/voice; children's shows, such as ''[[Pumper Pups]]'', which he narrated, in addition to comedic film roles. The sibling relationship with his elder brother, [[the Honourable]] [[Erik Nielsen]], a former [[Prime Minister of Canada|Deputy Prime Minister of Canada]], served as the premise of an [[HBO]] [[mockumentary]] entitled ''[[The Canadian Conspiracy]]'' in which Leslie Nielsen appeared, along with other prominent Canadian-born media personalities. He was a celebrity contestant on CBS's ''[[Gameshow Marathon (U.S. TV series)|Gameshow Marathon]]'', where he played ''[[The Price Is Right]]'', ''[[Let's Make a Deal]]'', ''[[Beat the Clock]]'', and ''[[Press Your Luck]]'' for charity.&lt;ref name=&quot;CBS&quot;/&gt;

Beginning in February 2007, Nielsen began playing a small role as a doctor in the humorous yet educational television show ''[[Doctor*Ology]]''. The show chronicles real-life medical techniques and technology, and airs on the [[Discovery Channel]]. In an interview, Nielsen admitted his admiration for the doctors on the show: &quot;There are any number of things that you think about when you ponder if you hadn't been an actor, what would you be, and I've always said I'd like to be an astronaut or a doctor. I have such admiration for doctors. I just don't know how you go around to thank them enough for coming up with the world's most remarkable new discoveries.&quot;&lt;ref name=&quot;YahooNe&quot;&gt;{{cite news|title=Legendary Leslie Nielsen reluctant to slow down at 81|work=[[The Vancouver Sun]]|date=2 March 2007}}&lt;/ref&gt;

In 2007, Nielsen starred in the drama ''[[Music Within]]''. In 2008, he portrayed a version of [[Uncle Ben]] for ''[[Superhero Movie]]'', a spoof of [[superhero]] films. He then appeared in the 2008 parody film ''[[An American Carol]]'', which David Zucker directed, produced, and co-wrote. He appeared in the 2009 parody ''[[Stan Helsing]]''. Nielsen portrayed the Doctor in the Spanish horror comedy ''Spanish Movie'',&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|url=http://www.dreadcentral.com/news/34842/spanish-movie-looking-bring-some-comedy-spanish-horror |title=Spanish Movie Looking to Bring Some Comedy into Spanish Horror |publisher=Dreadcentral.com|archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5ufXJQckR|date=7 December 2009|archivedate=2 December 2010}}&lt;/ref&gt; a spoof comedy like ''[[Scary Movie]]'', but making fun of popular Spanish films.&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|url=http://www.bloody-disgusting.com/news/18301 |title='Spanish Movie' Spoofs Popular Flicks from Spain|publisher=Bloody-disgusting.com|date=7 December 2009|archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5ufXNdki2|archivedate=2 December 2010}}&lt;/ref&gt;

Nielsen appeared in over 100 films and 1,500 television programs over the span of his career, portraying over 220 characters.&lt;ref name=&quot;CWOF&quot;&gt;{{cite web|title=Leslie Nielsen, 2001 Inductee|work=Canadaswalkoffame.com|url=http://www.canadaswalkoffame.com/inductee/leslie-nielsen|archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5ufXRWkzX|archivedate=2 December 2010}}&lt;/ref&gt;&lt;ref name=&quot;1500Greensboro&quot;&gt;{{cite news|last=Leonard|first=J.T.|title=Nielsen Serious About Clarence Darrow Role|work=Greensboro News and Record|date=10 February 2000|url=http://nl.newsbank.com/nl-search/we/Archives?p_product=GB&amp;p_theme=gb&amp;p_action=search&amp;p_maxdocs=200&amp;p_topdoc=1&amp;p_text_direct-0=0EAF88A65E1BB178&amp;p_field_direct-0=document_id&amp;p_perpage=10&amp;p_sort=YMD_date:D&amp;s_trackval=GooglePM|format=Fee required|accessdate=23 February 2009}}&lt;/ref&gt;

==Personal life==
{{Quote box|width=30em|bgcolor=#c6dbf7|quote=&quot;I'm afraid if I don't keep moving, they're going to catch me&amp;nbsp;... I am 81 years old and I want to see what's around the corner, and I don't see any reason in the world not to keep working. But I am starting to value my down time a great deal because I am realizing there might be other things to do that I am overlooking.&quot;|source=—Nielsen reflecting on his career in 2007&lt;ref name=&quot;YahooNe&quot;/&gt;}}

Nielsen married four times: [[Monica Boyar]] (1950–1956), Alisande Ullman (1958–1973), Brooks Oliver (1981–1983) and Barbaree Earl (2001–2010).&lt;ref name=&quot;NNDB&quot;&gt;{{cite web|title=Leslie Nielsen|work=[[NNDB]]|url=http://www.nndb.com/people/158/000023089/|archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5ufXUDouV|archivedate=2 December 2010}}&lt;/ref&gt;&lt;ref name=&quot;Yahoo&quot;&gt;{{cite web|title=Leslie Nielsen|work=[[Yahoo! Movies]]|url=http://movies.yahoo.com/movie/contributor/1800014430/bio|archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5ufXWHnju|archivedate=2 December 2010}}&lt;/ref&gt; Nielsen had two daughters from his second marriage, Maura and Thea Nielsen.&lt;ref name=&quot;Yahoo&quot;/&gt;

Nielsen was a fan of [[golf]], and he often played it in his free time.&lt;ref name=&quot;Tribute&quot;&gt;{{cite web|title=Leslie Nielsen|work=Tribute.ca|url=http://www.tribute.ca/people/leslie-nielsen/1314/|archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5ufXYuAD0|archivedate=2 December 2010}}&lt;/ref&gt; Nielsen joked about his view on golf, &quot;I have no goals or ambition. I do, however, wish to work enough to maintain whatever celebrity status I have so that they will continue to invite me to golf tournaments.&quot;&lt;ref name=&quot;Tribute&quot;/&gt; Nielsen's interest in the sport led him to star in several comedic instructional films.

Nielsen stated in several interviews that he had a few medical problems such as [[Deafness|hearing impairment]].&lt;ref name=&quot;Audio&quot;&gt;{{cite web|title=Interview with Leslie Nielsen Actor and Comedian|work=AudiologyOnline.com|url=http://www.audiologyonline.com/interview/interview_detail.asp?interview_id=163|date=9 December 2002|archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5ufXiN3qh|archivedate=2 December 2010}}&lt;/ref&gt; He was legally deaf and wore hearing aids for most of his life.&lt;ref name=Shirley /&gt; Because of this impairment, he publicly supported the Better Hearing Institute.&lt;ref name=&quot;BHISupport&quot;&gt;{{cite web|title=About BHI- Celebrities Who Have Supported BHI|work=Better Hearing Institute|url=http://www.betterhearing.org/about/celeb.cfm|archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5ufXlPzrS|archivedate=2 December 2010}}&lt;/ref&gt;

==Death==
[[File:Leslie Nielsen Headstone.jpg|thumb|alt=Leslie Nielsen Gravestone|Leslie Nielsen's Gravestone bearing his epitaph]]In November 2010, Nielsen was admitted to a Fort Lauderdale, Florida hospital for treatment of [[pneumonia]]. On 28 November, Doug Nielsen, Nielsen's nephew, announced to the [[CJOB]] radio station that Nielsen had died in his sleep, due to complications from pneumonia, around 5:30&amp;nbsp;pm EST, surrounded by family and friends.&lt;ref name=&quot;CJOBAudio&quot;&gt;{{cite news|title=Leslie Nielsen dead at 84|publisher=[[CJOB]]|url=http://www.cjob.com/Landing/Story.aspx?ID=1318402|date=28 November 2010|archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5ufXnxiGg|archivedate=2 December 2010}}&lt;/ref&gt;&lt;ref name=&quot;CNNOb&quot;&gt;{{cite news|url=http://www.cnn.com/2010/SHOWBIZ/Movies/11/28/obit.leslie.nielsen/index.html?hpt=T1|title=Leslie Nielsen, star of 'Airplane!' and 'Naked Gun,' dead at 84|publisher=[[CNN]]|date=28 November 2010|archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5ufXrYBOr|archivedate=2 December 2010}}&lt;/ref&gt;&lt;ref name=&quot;CanadaOn&quot;&gt;{{cite news|agency=[[Postmedia News]]|url=http://www.canada.com/sports/baseball/Canadian+movie+star+Leslie+Nielsen+dead/3897133/story.html|title=Canadian movie star Leslie Nielsen dead at 84|publisher=[[Postmedia News|Canada.com]]|date=2 November 2010|archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5ufY1V5ly|archivedate=2 December 2010}}&lt;/ref&gt; He was interred in Fort Lauderdale's Evergreen Cemetery. As a final bit of humor, Nielsen chose &quot;Let 'er Rip&quot; as his [[epitaph]].&lt;ref&gt;{{cite news |url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/tvshowbiz/article-1394065/Leslie-Nielsen-keeps-fans-laughing-grave.html |date=3 June 2011 |title=Leslie Nielsen keeps fans laughing from beyond the grave with 'let 'er rip' epitaph
|author= Debbie Emery |location=London |work=Daily Mail}}&lt;/ref&gt;

==Achievements==
Among his numerous awards, in 1995 Leslie Nielsen received [[University of California, Los Angeles|UCLA]]'s Jack Benny Award for his comedic roles.&lt;ref name=&quot;BIO&quot;/&gt; In 1988, he became the 1,884th personality to receive a star on the [[Hollywood Walk of Fame]] at 6541 Hollywood Blvd.&lt;ref name=&quot;CityN&quot;&gt;{{cite news|title=Leslie Nielsen Gets Star on Walk of Fame|work=[[Deseret News]]|url=http://archive.deseretnews.com/archive/26629/LESLIE-NIELSEN-GETS-STAR-ON-WALK-OF-FAME.html|date=12 December 1988|archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5ufY4CIWc|archivedate=2 December 2010}}&lt;/ref&gt; In 2001 he was inducted into [[Canada's Walk of Fame]].&lt;ref name=&quot;hon1&quot;&gt;{{cite web|title=The Canada Honours|publisher=Canada's Walk of Fame|url=http://www.canadaswalkoffame.com/inductee/leslie-nielsen|year=2010|accessdate=1 January 2011}}&lt;/ref&gt; The following year he was made an Officer of the [[Order of Canada]], although he was also a naturalized U.S. citizen.&lt;ref name=&quot;Record&quot;/&gt; With his American status, he maintained his Canadian heritage: &quot;There's no way you can be a Canadian and think you can lose it&amp;nbsp;... Canadians are a goodly group. They are very aware of caring and helping.&quot;&lt;ref name=&quot;Record&quot;/&gt; On 19 May 2005, during the centennial gala of his birth province, [[Saskatchewan]], Leslie Nielsen was introduced to [[Elizabeth II|HM Queen Elizabeth II]].&lt;ref name=&quot;Queen&quot;&gt;{{cite news|title=The Royal Homecoming|work=Centennial|url=http://www.monarchist-nsb.ca/download/centennial-edition-league-news-2005.pdf.pdf|archiveurl=http://web.archive.org/web/20070704074620/http://www.monarchist-nsb.ca/download/centennial-edition-league-news-2005.pdf.pdf|archivedate=4 July 2007|format=PDF|accessdate=22 February 2009}}&lt;/ref&gt;

In 1997, a Golden Palm Star on the [[Palm Springs, California]], [[Palm Springs Walk of Stars|Walk of Stars]] was dedicated to him.&lt;ref&gt;[http://www.palmspringswalkofstars.com/web-storage/Stars/Stars%20dedicated%20by%20date.pdf Palm Springs Walk of Stars by date dedicated]&lt;/ref&gt;

On 20 February 2002, Nielsen was named an honorary citizen of [[West Virginia]] and an &quot;Ambassador of Mountain State Goodwill&quot;. Nielsen visited the state many times to speak and visit friends.&lt;ref&gt;{{cite news|url=http://news.google.com/newspapers?id=VPwrAAAAIBAJ&amp;sjid=RG0FAAAAIBAJ&amp;pg=2223,5021078&amp;dq=leslie+nielsen&amp;hl=en|title=Nielsen Honored By West Virginia|date=21 February 2002|work=Kentucky New Era|accessdate=28 November 2010}}&lt;/ref&gt; In 2003, in honor of Nielsen, [[Grant MacEwan University|Grant MacEwan College]] named its school of communications after him.&lt;ref name=&quot;CBCAwards&quot;&gt;{{cite news|title=Leslie Nielsen wins excellence award|publisher=[[CBC News]]|url=http://www.cbc.ca/arts/story/2003/10/23/nielsenaward231003.html|date=23 October 2003|archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5ufYB1tyr|archivedate=2 December 2010}}&lt;/ref&gt; Also in 2003, the [[ACTRA|Alliance of Canadian Cinema, Television and Radio Artists]] awarded him the ACTRA Award of Excellence.&lt;ref name=&quot;CBCAwards&quot;/&gt;

'''Ivan &quot;Ivo&quot; Andrić''' ({{lang-sr-cyr|Иво Андрић}}, {{IPA-sh|ǐʋan ǐːʋɔ ǎːndritɕ|pron}}) (9 October 1892 – 13 March 1975) was a [[Yugoslavs|Yugoslav]] novelist,&lt;ref&gt;Zoltan D. Barany, ''The East European Gypsies: Regime Change, Marginality, and Ethnopolitics'' (Cambridge University Press, 2001: ISBN 0-521-00910-3),[http://books.google.com/books?id=yTylND961ZMC&amp;pg=PA59 p. 59].&lt;/ref&gt;&lt;ref&gt;Rajko Đurić, ''Romanies and Europe: Romanies as Characters in European Literature'' (Council of Europe, 1996: ISBN 92-871-2855-3), [http://books.google.com/books?id=vbcK0mnVVuwC&amp;pg=PA11 p. 11].&lt;/ref&gt; short story writer, and the 1961 winner of the [[Nobel Prize in Literature]].&lt;ref name = NYTimes/&gt; His writings dealt mainly with life in his native [[Bosnia Eyalet|Bosnia]] under the [[Ottoman Empire]]. His native house in [[Travnik]] has been transformed into a Museum, and his [[Belgrade]] flat on [[Andrićev Venac]] hosts the [[Museum of Ivo Andrić]], and [[Ivo Andrić Foundation]].

==Biography==
Ivan Andrić was born on 9 October 1892, to [[Croats|Croatia]]n&lt;ref&gt;http://www.library.yale.edu/slavic/croatia/literature/literature.html&lt;/ref&gt;&lt;ref&gt;http://ivoandric.cz/en/biography&lt;/ref&gt; parents in [[Travnik]], [[Bosnia and Herzegovina]], then part of [[Austria-Hungary]]. He was born as Ivan, but became known by the [[diminutive]] Ivo. When Andrić was two years old, his father Antun died. Because his mother Katarina was too poor to support him, he was raised by his mother's family in the town of [[Višegrad]] on the river [[Drina River|Drina]] in eastern [[Bosnia and Herzegovina|Bosnia]], where he saw the 16th-century [[Mehmed Paša Sokolović Bridge]], later made famous in his novel ''[[The Bridge on the Drina]]'' (''Na Drini ćuprija'').&lt;ref&gt;Richard C. Frucht (ed.), ''Eastern Europe: An Introduction to the People, Lands, and Culture'' (ABC-CLIO, 2005: ISBN 1-57607-800-0), [http://books.google.com/books?id=lVBB1a0rC70C&amp;pg=RA2-PA568 p. 568].&lt;/ref&gt;

Andrić attended the Jesuit gymnasium in [[Travnik]], followed by [[Sarajevo]]'s [[Gymnasium (school)|gymnasium]] and later he studied philosophy at the Universities of [[Zagreb]] (1912 and 1918), [[Vienna]] (1913), [[Kraków]] (1914), and [[Graz]] (PhD, 1924).&lt;ref&gt;&quot;[http://www.encyclopedia.com/doc/1G2-3435000021.html Andrić, Ivo],&quot; ''Encyclopedia of World Biography'', 2005.&lt;/ref&gt; Because of his political activities, Andrić was imprisoned by the Austrian government during [[World War I]] (first in [[Maribor]] and later in the [[Doboj]] detention camp) alongside other pro-Yugoslav civilians.

Andric started his literary career as a poet. In 1914 he was one of the contributors to Hrvatska mlada lirika (Young Croatian Lyrics).&lt;ref&gt;&quot;[http://nobelprize.org/nobel_prizes/literature/laureates/1961/andric-bio.html The Nobel Prize in Literature 1961]&lt;/ref&gt;

Under the newly-formed [[Kingdom of Yugoslavia|Kingdom of Serbs, Croats, and Slovenes]] (later [[Kingdom of Yugoslavia]]) Andrić became a civil servant, first in the Ministry of Faiths and then the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, where he pursued a successful diplomatic career as Deputy Foreign Minister.

During his diplomatic service, he worked in embassy at [[Holy See]] (1920), consulates in [[Bucharest]], [[Trieste]] and Graz (1924), consulates in Paris and [[Marseilles]] (1927), and embassy in [[Madrid]] (1928). In 1939 he was appointed ambassador in Germany. He was also a delegate of the Kingdom of Yugoslavia at the 19th, 21st, 23rd and 24th sessions of the [[League of Nations]] in Geneva in period 1930–1934.&lt;ref&gt;[http://www.indiana.edu/~league/assemblydelega.htm List of Assembly Delegates and Substitutes – (A)] from League of Nations Photo Archive at the University of Indiana&lt;/ref&gt; Andrić greatly opposed the movement of [[Stjepan Radić]], the president of the [[Croatian Peasant Party]]. His ambassadorship ended in 1941 after the German invasion of Yugoslavia. During [[World War II]], Andrić lived quietly in [[Belgrade]], completing  three of his most famous novels which were published in 1945, including ''The Bridge on the Drina''.

After the war, Andrić spent most of his time in his home in [[Belgrade]] and held a number of ceremonial posts in the new Communist government of Yugoslavia, and was also a member of the Parliament of Bosnia and Herzegovina. In 1961, he was awarded the Nobel Prize for Literature &quot;for the epic force with which he has traced themes and depicted human destinies drawn from the history of his country&quot;. He donated all of the prize money for the improvement of libraries in Bosnia and Herzegovina. He was member of the [[Serbian Academy of Sciences and Arts]].&lt;ref&gt;[http://www.sanu.ac.rs/English/Adresar.aspx SANU]&lt;/ref&gt;

Following the death of his second wife, Milica Babić-Andrić, in 1968, he began reducing his public activities. In 1969 he was elected an honorary member of the [[Academy of Sciences and Arts of Bosnia and Herzegovina]].&lt;ref&gt;Akademija nauka i umjetnosti Bosne i Hercegovine, [http://www.anubih.ba/index.php?option=content&amp;lang=eng&amp;Theme=honorary&amp;Level=2&amp;ItemID=6 Honorary members]&lt;/ref&gt; and in 1972 the [[University of Belgrade]] awarded him an honorary doctorate.&lt;ref&gt;Univerzitet u Beogradu: [http://www.bg.ac.rs/csrp/nauka/pocasni_doktori.php počasni doktori]&lt;/ref&gt; As time went by, he grew increasingly ill and eventually died on 13 March 1975, in [[Belgrade]], [[SR Serbia]], [[Socialist Federal Republic of Yugoslavia|SFR Yugoslavia]].

He was buried in the [[Novo groblje|Belgrade New Cemetery]], in the [[Novo groblje#Alley of Distinguished Citizens|Alley of Distinguished Citizens]].&lt;ref&gt;[http://www.beogradskagroblja.rs/licnosti.php?lan=eng&amp;id=5 Ivo Andrić, Novo Groblje]&lt;/ref&gt;

==Works==
[[File:Ivo Andric in Višegrad.jpg|thumb|right|Ivo Andrić and [[Mehmed Paša Sokolović Bridge]] in [[Višegrad]], Bosnia and Herzegovina]]
The material for his works was mainly drawn from the [[History of Bosnia and Herzegovina|history]], [[folklore]], and [[Bosnian Culture|culture]] of his native [[Bosnia and Herzegovina|Bosnia]].
[[Image:Ivo Andric Beograd spomenik.jpg|thumb|right|Ivo Andrić monument in [[Belgrade]], Serbia]]
* ''[[The Bridge on the Drina]]''
* ''Bosnian Chronicle''&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|url=http://www.ivoandric.org.rs/html/bosnian_chronicle.html |title=Bosnian Chronicle |publisher=Ivoandric.org.rs|accessdate=June 15, 2011}}&lt;/ref&gt; (a.k.a. ''Chronicles of Travnik'')
* ''The Woman from Sarajevo''&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|url=http://www.ivoandric.org.rs/html/body_the_woman_from_sarajevo.html |title=The Woman from Sarajevo|publisher=Ivoandric.org.rs |accessdate=June 15, 2011}}&lt;/ref&gt;

Those were all released in 1945 and written during [[World War II]] while Andrić was living quietly in Belgrade. They are often referred to as the''&quot;Bosnian trilogy&quot;'' as they were released simultaneously and had been written in the same period. However, they are connected only thematically—they are indeed three completely different works.

Some of his other popular works include:
*''Ex Ponto''&lt;ref name=&quot;ivoandric1&quot;&gt;{{cite web|url=http://www.ivoandric.org.rs/html/lyricists.html |title=Lyricists |publisher=Ivoandric.org.rs|accessdate=June 15, 2011}}&lt;/ref&gt; (1918)
*''Unrest''&lt;ref name=&quot;ivoandric1&quot;/&gt; (''Nemiri'', 1920)
*''The Journey of Alija Đerzelez''&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|url=http://www.ivoandric.org.rs/html/the_journey_of_ali_djerzelez.html |title=The Journey of Ali Djerzelez |publisher=Ivoandric.org.rs |accessdate=June 15, 2011}}&lt;/ref&gt; (''Put Alije Đerzeleza'', 1920)
*''The Vizier's Elephant''&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|url=http://www.ivoandric.org.rs/html/body_andric_s_treasury_ii.html#Elephant |title=Andric's Treasury II|publisher=Ivoandric.org.rs |accessdate=June 15, 2011}}&lt;/ref&gt; (''Priča o vezirovom slonu'', 1948; trans. 1962)
*''The Damned Yard''&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|url=http://www.ivoandric.org.rs/html/the_damned_yard.html |title=The Damned Yard |publisher=Ivoandric.org.rs|accessdate=June 15, 2011}}&lt;/ref&gt; (''Prokleta avlija'', 1954)
*''Omer-Pasha Latas''&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|url=http://www.ivoandric.org.rs/html/omer_pasha_latas.html |title=Omer Pasha Latas |publisher=Ivoandric.org.rs|accessdate=June 15, 2011}}&lt;/ref&gt; (''Omerpaša Latas'', released posthumously in 1977)

His manuscripts and literary legacy are in the custody of the foundation he founded ([[Museum of Ivo Andrić|Fondacija Ive Andrića]]) and [[Serbian Academy of Sciences and Arts]].&lt;ref&gt;Ivo Andrić Foundation, [http://www.ivoandric.org.rs/html/work.html Work]&lt;/ref&gt; Some of his manuscripts and literary legacy are in custody of the [[Croatian Academy of Sciences and Arts]], the Institute for the History of Croatian Literature, Theater and Music in Zagreb.&lt;ref name=&quot;Sapunar&quot;&gt;{{cite book |last=Sapunar |first=Andrea |editor1-last=Sabljak |editor1-first=Tomislav |editor2-last=Hećimović |editor2-first=Branko |editor3-last=Katalinić |editor3-first=Vjera |editor4-last=Matičević |editor4-first=Ivica |title=Vodič Zavoda za povijest hrvatske književnosti, kazališta i glazbe Hrvatske akademije znanosti i umjetnosti |publisher=Hrvatska akademija znanosti i umjetnosti |location=Zagreb |year=2001 |pages=111.–120 |chapter=Popis rukopisnih ostavština u Arhivu Odsjeka}}&lt;/ref&gt;

Some claim that the works of Andrić, particularly his thesis ''The Development of Spiritual Life in Bosnia under the Influence of Turkish Rule'' have resurfaced as a source of [[anti-Muslim]] prejudice in Serbian cultural discourse.&lt;ref&gt;Ammiel Alcalay, ''Memories of Our Future: Selected Essays 1982–1999'' (City Lights Books, 1999: ISBN 0-87286-360-3), [http://books.google.com/books?id=4mBwBf-U-lQC&amp;pg=PA233 p. 233].&lt;/ref&gt;

==Classification==
[[Image:Ivo Andric declaring himself as Croat.jpg|thumb|left|Records of the [[Jagiellonian University]] in Kraków, Poland, show that Andrić enrolled there as a [[Croats|Croat]] in 1914.]]
[[Image:Ivo Andric declaring himself as Serb.jpg|thumb|left|In Yugoslav identity card issued in June 1951, Andrić declaring himself a [[Serbs|Serb]].]]
Because of Andrić's unique circumstances (born in Bosnia to Croat parents, later living and working in Serbia), he is claimed as part of [[Serbian literature]],&lt;ref name =Sells&gt;{{cite web | url = http://www.haverford.edu/relg/sells/postings/bogomils_race_andric.html | title = Of Bogomils, Race, and Ivo Andric | date = July 3, 1996 | first = Michael | last = Sells | authorlink = Michael Sells }}&lt;/ref&gt;&lt;ref&gt;Enes Cengic, ''Krleža post mortem'' I-III. Svjetlost, Sarajevo, 1990. 2. part, pages 171–172  – here Andrić refuses to be listed as a Croat&lt;/ref&gt;&lt;ref&gt;Borislav Mihailović – Mihiz: ''Autobiografija – o drugima, Druga knjiga'', page 137. BIGZ, 1995&lt;/ref&gt;&lt;ref&gt;[http://www.matica.hr/vijenac/vij206.nsf/AllWebDocs/Hrvatskinobelovci Hrvatski nobelovci] {{hr icon}}&lt;/ref&gt; [[Croatian literature]],&lt;ref name = NYTimes&gt;{{cite news | url = http://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9F0CE7D91531F93BA25757C0A965958260&amp;sec=&amp;spon=&amp;pagewanted=all | title = A Reader's Guide to the Balkans | first = Robert D. | last = Kaplan | date = April 18, 1993 |work=New York Times }}&lt;/ref&gt;&lt;ref name=Yale&gt;Yale University Library: Slavic, East European &amp; Central Asian Collections,[http://www.library.yale.edu/slavic/croatia/literature/literature.html Croatia: Themes, Authors, Books].&lt;/ref&gt; and [[Bosnian literature]].&lt;ref name=britannica&gt;{{cite web |url=http://www.britannica.com/EBchecked/topic/24035/Ivo-Andric |title=Ivo Andrić|year=2010|publisher=Encyclopædia Britannica Online |accessdate=March 1, 2010}}&lt;/ref&gt; Throughout his life, he worked in all three countries and contributed material to their various publications. In terms of what language or dialect he wrote in, he wrote in [[Serbo-Croatian]], which was officially considered one language in Yugoslavia; he had been a believer in [[Yugoslavs|Yugoslav]] unity and [[Pan-slavism]]. However, it must be mentioned that [[Serbo-Croatian]] used to have two different subtypes – the Eastern standardization (spread in [[Montenegro]], Serbia and partly in [[Bosnia and Herzegovina]]), and Western standardization that is common in [[Croatia]] and partly in Bosnia and Herzegovina. Although Andrić mostly used the Serbian form of Serbo-Croatian ([[ekavian accent]] of Shtokavian dialect, commonly spoken in Serbia), his early works were written in the Bosnian-Croatian-Montenegrin form ([[ijekavian accent]] of the Shtokavian dialect, commonly spoken in Bosnia).&lt;ref name=britannica/&gt;

There was also a more specific, and more fundamental, divide—that between [[ekavian]] and [[ijekavian]] standards of then-[[Serbo-Croat]] – Andrić wrote in the ijekavian form (standard in both Western standard Croatia, middle-of-the-road standard Bosnia-Herzegovina, and Eastern standard Montenegro) only in his youth. As a mature writer, he wrote and published in ekavian (the official standard only in Serbia), even when depicting characters who live in Bosnia and who are quoted as speaking ijekavian accent in the dialogues, that stand out in otherwise ekavian text.

Andrić never used the translated equivalents of foreign words, as used to be common in Eastern standard.
[[File:Grob Ive Andrića.jpg|thumb|Ivo Andrić's grave in Belgrade, Serbia.]]
Bosnians celebrate Andrić as a native son, as he was born and raised in Bosnia and set most of his stories in his native land. His doctoral thesis was on the cultural history of Bosnia under Turkish rule titled ''The Development of Spiritual Life in Bosnia under the Influence of Turkish Rule'', an example of one of his many writings dealing with Bosnia.

Croatians point to his Croat heritage—both of his parents were Roman Catholic Croats in Bosnia. He declared himself a Croat while studying in Kraków in 1914, and had his work published in various Croatian publications. Andrić wrote in the Serbo-Croatian language's ijekavian accent until the formation of the Kingdom of the Serbs, Croats, and Slovenes (later the Kingdom of Yugoslavia) and his move to Belgrade, where he began writing in Serbian and embraced the Yugoslav cause.

Serbian sources claim him as a Serbian writer, saying that he mainly wrote in the ekavian standard that exists only in the Serbian language. He declared himself a Serb when he married Serbian Milica Babić at the age of 67 in 1958.&lt;ref name=&quot;Radovan Popović page 240&quot;&gt;''[http://books.google.com/books?id=Z_DGSAAACAAJ&amp;dq=Andri%C4%87eva%20prijateljstva&amp;source=gbs_book_other_versions Andrićeva prijateljstva]'', Radovan Popović, 2009, page 240&lt;/ref&gt; He also became a member of the [[Serbian Academy of Science and Arts]].

    <title>Fusion power</title>
    <ns>0</ns>

    <revision>
